description:
This place is surprisingly clean!

What I tried:
*Bun bo hue - yum! 

Overall thoughts:
*Been meaning to try this place out since there isn't too many places to get bun bo hue in Richmond district, sf. 

*Service is good and very clean compared to many other Vietnamese restaurants I've been to. 

*Food was good but a little more pricy than other Vietnamese places. It was worth it tho. Definitely would come back to try other items.
author: Sarah W.

description:
This review is strictly on their customer service. 

Food was okay, however this was the worst customer service I've ever experienced! I've never felt so devalued as a customer. I ordered online and came in to pick up my order. Walked up to the register and the lady working the register did not look up or acknowledge me at all. So I waited and stood there...awkwardly. And when a second lady came up and finally looked available, I tried to ask about my take out order. But the first woman butted in and told me in an extremely rude tone that I had to wait a minute and they were very busy (ringing up credit cards). Collecting that money is so much more important. Obviously if she said that the moment I went up I would have been happy to stand aside and wait until they were ready. She treated me like I had no manners when honestly she needs to work on hers. Never coming back here.
author: Sharyn Y.

description:
I think Y and Y takes the cake for the multitude of Vietnamese restaurants in the Richmond District! Personally, I like the soup as spicy and zesty as possible, which the restaurant did, providing a generous portion of spring onions. The only slight negative is that the meat was kind of bland. I think for most or all the pho there is no small or large portion. Other than that, you get a decent amount of noodles and the soup is addicting! A differentiating factor is the omelette dish, which is savory pork encased in a crispy omelette - excellent flavors! 

Thankfully, the place is rather affordable compared to other Vietnamese restaurants. A bowl of Pho is around $10. On the expensive side, the avocado milkshake is delicious, but comes at a hefty price of $6.00. The only kinds of downsides to this place is that it is on the small side, so bringing in a big group would be difficult. Also, a few of the small sauce dishes were not 100% clean. The waiters and waitresses have pretty good attitudes, from the few times I've been there.
author: Louis Suo L.

description: Great tomato based beef noodle soup. Haven't taste one that good for a long while. A bit pricy, so deduct a point.
author: zoom z.

description: Seriously the best 5 spice chicken soup ever. Crispy, but not deep fried. The lemongrass beef is amazing, too (rice plate). They serve the chicken on the side so it doesn't get soggy in the broth. Order online through yelp app or call in, or go in! It's worth it :).
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Solid Vietnamese restaurant -- my family's go-to in the area if I'm not near Kevin's on Irving/not willing to drive far. This place gets busy during peak hours since there are only about 10 tables. It's a small restaurant, family-owned and the boss lady wearing green is badass, friendly, and efficient (her brother runs the Yummy Yummy on Irving). I've tried a couple items but will rave about two that I order often: pho #25 and #4 bbq pork spring roll appetizer.

Their pho #25 is my favorite. I love everything, the broth - light and flavorful, noodles - not overcooked or soggy at all, and particularly love their beef balls--they're quite big and has a springiness texture to it. They only serve the pho in one size, but you can add extra noodles for an additional charge. If you order pho, they also give you a plate of bean sprouts, jalapeños, basil, cilantro, and lemons. 

I also enjoy the bbq pork spring rolls appetizer #4. The bbq pork is charbroiled and it's SO good, wrapped in a bed of noodles and lettuce. Comes in 6 pieces. Haven't left feeling dissatisfied after a handful of visits here-- I'm a fan of this place and will return.
author: Debby N.

description: They no longer serve Banh Beo, they changed their menu recently. I drove here for Banh Beo because I didn't want to drive to San Jose. Ended up getting their banh uot dac biet dish, still very satisfying. Noodles were freshly steamed and it came with fancy pork, shredded pork, and shrimp cake. The boyfriend got their five spice chicken noodle soup, amazing no complaints. The lady that serve us used to own Irving Cafe in outer mission, miss them so much. Overall, this place is great, they serve noodle soup, non noodle soup dish, and sandwiches!
author: Suzy Z.

description: Very friendly staff and the pho and the bbq pork sandwich hit the spot! I definitely recommend coming here for lunch or dinner.
author: Jen T.

description:
I came here last night with a friend because we were looking for banh bot chien and it exceeded my expectations.  I usually go to SJ for viet food because it's difficult to find authentic Vietnamese food in SF that fits my taste palate since I grew up around a predominately Vietnamese community.

While most people around us seemed to be ordering pho or vermicelli noodles (bun thit nuong), we decided to be a bit more adventurous and order a variety of appetizer dishes.

Banh bot chien trung - (fried rice cakes w/ eggs) 10/10 this was probably the best of the 4 dishes.  Served extra hot and with a tasty sweet soy sauce
 
Banh Xeo -  (fried egg crepe) 8/10 good crispiness and flavor but I've had better 

Cha Gio - (egg rolls/fried spring rolls) 9/10 the fried skin of the egg roll was very tasty

Ngheu nuong mo hanh - (grilled clams in buttered onions) 6/10 I'm just glad I was able to find this in the city but overall it was meh.  Wouldn't order it again from here.  It would have been better if it was mussels instead.  The ginger fish sauce that was included with it was just OK too

Service and cleanliness was what you would expect of a authentic Asian restaurant.  There wasn't a long line on a Friday night and food was served within 10 min of ordering.
author: Simon L.

description:
I've had better pho (I had the beef flank and beef ball pho) and I might have just gone on an off day. The broth was a bit on the watery side and was missing something. No amount of hoisin, Sriracha, like, or Thai basil was going to fix that mess. 

Suggested go to? The bun with roasted chicken in it. The skin is light and crispy and is definitely one of the better dishes on the menu. Although, they can be kind of inconsistent on moistness of the chicken depending on the day.
author: Gaelyn O.

description: Love their pho and spring rolls! I've gotten both 5+ times there and they're consistently good every time. Only con is that the place is super small so sometimes there's a wait and the tables are pretty close together so it can feel like you're dining with your neighbors. But go for the food- it's spot on.
author: Jenn A.

description:
I love the pho here! Granted, my soup was very basic (beef noodle soup with rare beef steak). I asked if they can add tendons with it and the staff was great in adding what I wanted.

I have to say, tendons seem to be a hit or miss at some of the Vietnamese restaurants I've eaten at - some are hard which I don't like and others are deliciously slimy and soft. The tendons were definitely on point here. There was something about the noodles that set this restaurant apart from previous ones...they were more firm in texture. Whatever noodles they used, it was delicious!!

I will say that the staff seemed a bit unorganized at one point. One of the ladies came up to me and offered me a bahn mi until I told her that that's not what I ordered. Shortly after we found out that the family over to my right were the ones who ordered the sandwich. We laughed it off. No big deal, I've just never experienced that mix up type of situation before.
author: Marissa D.

description:
This review is specifically for #37, the spicy beef and pork noodle soup aka bun bo hue.

This was my first time ever trying this dish so I have nothing to compare it to but overall it was okay although not sure yet that I'm a fan. Unfortunately the pork wasn't well cleaned, see photo, and so it put me off from eating any of the meats except for the sausage.

Maybe I'll give the dish another chance in the future.
author: Hello E.

description:
This restaurant is mediocre to me. Seems like they're popular for their pho. Which I didn't get. Instead I got Mien Ga which is chicken glass noodle soup and - order of there banh beo.

Chicken Glass Noodle Soup
It was actually good. I like my broth clearer though. I can definitely taste the fish sauce(the bottle not the house made kind) ratio was heavy on this one. 

Banh Béo
Definitely a let down and it was the reason why I wanted to go here in the first place. At first the presentation looks nice, but the rice cake itself is cracked all over and not supple looking like how you would get it when it's freshly made. 

I hate their dipping sauce the most!! Their house made dipping sauce for this dish stinks! And yes I know house made fish sauce smells 'cause I used to work at Vietnamese restaurant. When I tell you it stinks, it stinks like fart. I tried their shredded pickled carrots the comes with it and it was just as bad. I just hope I just got a bad batch of their dipping sauce, if not then I definitely would be weary, cause it doesn't smell right! Also, I find this dish overpriced $9.25 I would definitely skip it.

The only thing I like were the toppings-- the fried shallots, shredded pork and the pork patty were great. The mung bean mixture was okay they just put uneven dollops of it here and there.

Restaurant
Very tight. Not great for a big party. Service was okay.
author: Hue H.

description: I do not know if the problem was that we are here on a Sunday, but the chicken curry was a watery broth with very unappetizing pieces of chicken and nothing else, the other dishes were passable looking but we couldn't eat any of it due to how bad  the curry looked.
author: J.M. B.

description: It is so good . The Fried spring rolls are so crunchy and they are so good. And the rice paper spring rolls are just as good. This place is so good
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Food: solid and decently priced. I actually really like this place. It's just chill. Foods good. I don't think I've had a bad meal there. There is a dish to make your own wrap at the table with a fun contraption of hot water and rice paper. I like them. The beef tomato rice noodle is good. That's what I usually get.

Place: don't expect too much. Decent service and fast. 

I'm a satisfied customer every time. I know what it is and I don't expect this place to be what's it's not.
author: P L.

description: Good Vietnamese place if you're on Clement! I came here with my family at around 10am on a Sunday (when they open), so the place was understandably empty. There was 7 of us and we were seated right away. I got the #25, the combination beef noodle soup. The soup/dish was alright, and the meat was pretty tender. A unique (at least to me) aspect is that they offer steamed or raw bean sprouts with the pho dishes, and since most places just serve the raw bean sprouts, we decided to get both to try them out! The service was quick and efficient, and the restaurant started filling up during my meal. Overall, a good place if you're craving Vietnamese food and if you're in the area!
author: Lisa C.

description: My favorite Pho place in the Inner Richmond. I believe the sister restaurant of Yummy Yummy in the Inner Sunset - another favorite!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Still in search of a good place in San Fran for Banh Canh. I ordered it here twice now and both times, it did not wow me. 

The food is mediocre but definitely a good quick meal for the area. You can hop in and out usually with either a small to no wait.
author: Mai W.

description:
It's a family own restaurant, so you may feel more homey yet professional.
We ordered vegetable spring roll which was served warm and was my favorite dish of the night.
The fried spring roll was just okay since I'm not a big fan of the fried.
I forgot the name of the main dish, which was grilled pork, finely w/thin rice
author: Mary C.

description:
Omg! The take out container for their noodle soup is a plastic container with a wide opening! Do you know what this means?!?! It means that it is reasonable to have a hot bowl of noodle soup for lunch in the office! I love my soup pippin hot. It's totally conceivable to pop the soup in the microwave, pour it into the container holding the noodles, and then enjoying a bowl of hot noodle soup in the office on a winter day. It's mind blowing! I realize how much time I just spent raving about a container but there has to be someone else out there sharing my excitement. No?

I tried their shrimp and tomato paste noodle soup #36. It's good. I don't know if it's awesome but definitely good enough. It's a little over $11 which I thought was a bit pricey. I'll be back though. Did I tell you about their take out container?!?!
author: Connie S.

description:
This post is LONG OVERDUE but I just wanted to say that, in my honest opinion, this is the best pho in the city.

I come here probably like twice a week - sometimes alone or with my boyfriend. Whenever friends or family visit me, I make sure we come here. 

I've ordered delivery/take out too and the broth is always still boiling hot at home. Perfect for the order I always get (#28) since the soup cooks my meat haha. Overall, Y & Y's has helped me get through the hangovers, the flu, and the stress from school lol and I can't recommend this place enough!
author: Sarah J.

description:
The worst papaya salad I've ever had. Thank you.
I ordered a papaya salad and it was horrible. The sauce is VERY sweet and not what I expected. The papaya salad has no flavor at all and after mixing with the sauce all o tasted is a weird sweetness.
It's not cheap too :) $10 
Thank you.
author: Maggie F.

description:
This is hands down one of the best vietnamese restaurants in the city, if not THE best. I'm reluctant to even write this review in fear that Y&Y becomes unbearably popular. 

Five spice chicken pho. What. The chicken is perfectly fried, full of flavor, and comes on the side so it doesn't get soggy. The chicken broth of the soup is exactly what I'm craving when either the city or myself is feeling under the weather--fog or fever, I'm here. 

Everything is delicious. Imperial rolls--to die for. The crepe thing, just wow.

I can't even right now. My mouth is salivating typing this. Just go.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Sister restaurant of yummy yummy on Irving st

My go to here is the sate beef noodle soup (number 42)

My friends had the bun rieu and bun bo hue. Both looked pretty good. I keep telling myself to try other items on the menu. 

Can't go wrong coming here for a bowl of noodles, some Vietnamese rolls, or beef carpaccio. 

You won't be disappointed.
author: Lyman C.

description: Looking for place to eat with no lines. And Great Vietnamese food..This place is.. straight to the point restaurant that serves  quality food at the heart Clement street..
author: Donovan L.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Thursday around 12:40 pm and got seated right away. This place usually gets packed .

I ordered the bbh and it was really good just missing all the vegetables that regular Vietnamese restaurants give you with bbh. They just gave us basil and mint and bean sprouts . The soup was flavorful and it stayed hot and spicy throughout the meal. I kept coughing it was so spicy I felt like I was smoking a joint for the first time while telling myself that's some good bbh.

I also ordered a combination sandwich with extra plate and no mayo and no cucumber , it was surprisingly delicious .

I come here because they have special Vietnamese dishes like the wood war pork wrapped in a clear noodle like crepe and the crab udon.

However I will stick to the sandwiches , pho with beef on the side and the bbh .
author: DOM d.

description: Stumbled upon this trying to find dinner on Clement Street. Small cozy place. Y is for yummy food. Good value too. Best five spice chicken. Crisp skin and not fatty.  Moist and tasty. Wonderful imperial roll too. Hubby had extra large noodle bowl that had slight tomato broth. I'd hit this place up again if in the mood for Vietnamese food if I'm in the hood.
author: Laine G.

description:
First time here... it'll be my last. 

Ordered the cold noodles with egg roll, which came out to $11. It was hella hot out, so got a soda lemonade to go with my meal. I asked my server for the check and found put that they charged me $6 for the drink!!! When I asked about this, she started mumbling while pointing at two different items on the menu and stating that it was because they served the drink with soda water, not tap. I couldn't believe what she was trying to do to justify charging $6 for lemon, sugar and soda water. 

Everything said and done, the food was okay, but not worth the price. The drink drove me away. Not coming back.
author: D L.

description:
Although I've eaten at Yummy Yummy a handful of times, I've never bothered writing a review for them.  Mostly because my most recent visit dates back to my pre-Yelping days (over eight years ago!), but also because, despite how long it's been, I vividly recall never feeling all that impressed by their food.  Granted, my experience was limited to just their pho, but I can't say I ever felt all that motivated to try anything else either.

Fast forward a ways and my friend and I found ourselves at Y & Y for lunch (Yummy Yummy's sister restaurant).  In this case though, I was actually kind of excited since I was both trying something new while also indirectly giving Yummy Yummy another shot (I've been curious).  While I can't say how similar the menu looks, it's definitely smaller in comparison.  Just like the restaurant itself; it looks about half the size (if that), so don't be surprised if you see a line.

Since I didn't see my go-to on the menu (Rare Steak and Tendon), I opted to get (#26) PHO TAI NAM - Beef Pho with Rare Steak and Well Done Flank ($9.25).  As a whole, my order felt a bit small for the money.  However, relative to the bowl's size, there was a good amount of beef and the ratio of meat-to-noodles was fair.  What's more, the latter had just the right bite.  Sadly though, the broth fell short.  It may have looked the part, but it wasn't as beefy as its appearance suggested and it needed more body.

As for the rest of the menu (starters, vermicelli, rice plates, etc.), I can't say how good they might be, but the photos and reviews on Yelp seem to do them justice.  Still, for me, THREE AND A HALF STARS rounded down (for now).  While it wasn't explicitly bad, nothing about the food sets Y & Y apart from the majority of pho restaurants out there.  Which is problematic since you don't have to go very far to find something better (like Good Noodle a few blocks down).
author: Mike L.

description:
legit pho in SF- excellent broth! 

Brought me back to life when I was dead from the night before. 

They have a bunch of other viet food if you want something else - all the usuals- summer rolls, viet iced coffee, etc.

Spacious and fast service!
author: Jessie H.

description: First time here. Ordered take out and boy did I make the right choice. Ordered the 44 and it was delicious. Ordered via the yelp app which made everything super easy. Will definitely be back to dine in and have some Pho.
author: Marisol T.

description:
Consistently good food. Can get busy in the evenings, just FYI. 

My favorite thing on the menu is the house special grilled pork, basically a wrap your own spring rolls deal that is always nice and fresh, never greasy.

I haven't fell in love with any of the appetizers but they're all just fine. I plan on trying the rare beef app next time around.

Mango pudding is just okay but it satisfied my sweet tooth today.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Good Vietnamese food here, which makes me come back once in a while.  On my most recent visit I ordered the #45 which is the imperial rolls with five spice chicken and vermicelli.  I love imperial rolls and they were good here.  I didn't want pho with the soup, so just having vermicelli is perfect.  Not too certain my chicken was 'five spice', but it was decent.

This place gets full quick but service is fast so people finish here pretty quick.
author: Karen L.

description: I came here after learning that Lime Tree up the block is closed on Mondays. I've been to a lot of Vietnamese places over the years and this is the first where I felt that one dish had a well represented, balanced palate. As soon as I was seated they served me a pot of complimentary tea, a welcome addition to the meal. I ordered the #45 Imperial Rolls and 5Spice Chicken on Vermicelli noodles and the reviews were right, the flavours were lovely and the chicken skin just perfectly crisped. Underneath the vermicelli I was pleased to discover a bed of minced lettuce, mint and cucumber, which gave a nice light finish to a slightly oily meat dish. Overall It was a light lunch for me, I normally need a lot to fill up, but I was quite satisfied with the portions. I will certainly be returning on a cold evening for some hot Pho!
author: Ayden G.

description:
When I'm in the Richmond and craving Vietnamese food, I think of two places: Turtle Tower and Y&Y.

FOOD: the usual go-to dishes are the bún bo hue and the banh Hoi. Bún bo hue is tasty and flavorful, full of 'content'. Banh Hoi portion is smaller than the usual expected portion, comes with only ten rice sheets/wraps and a bit skimpy on the pickled carrots and mint, but the plate is more then enough for me to feel content/full. The grilled beef is really really good, one of the best Vietnamese charcoal grilled beef I've had in the city. Husband usually gets the pho tai or pho duc biet, he likes the beefy-ness of the soup and the beef is beefy and of good quality. 

SERVICE: staff are nice and often more friendly compared to other Vietnamese restaurants. They always take our orders correctly and repeat what you ordered to check that they had it down correctly. 

SPACE: not a big restaurant, but seating is comfortable. Well lit. The place and dishes/utensils appear clean. 

When there is a wait (usually lunch on weekends), sign onto the waitlist that is on a clipboard by the entrance. Many people order take-out, especially for dinner on weeknights, so don't hesitate if you don't see the restaurant crowded. People start to spill in after 7:30-8pm on a weeknight. They accept credit card! Phew!
author: Iris H.

description:
We walked in...

"May I help you. Sit anywhere".

"We reserve the right to refuse service to anyone" sign behind the counter.

Server came once to take order and once to serve food. No one came to clear our dishes or ask if we needed anything or even to bring the check. Tea was cold quickly. No offer to refill.

When my wife had to go ASK TO PAY, three staff just stood there and stared at her.

We've had better pho and service in Antioch.

So much for "inclusive" SF. If you are a biracial couple don't bother.
author: Aaron L.

description: My fiance and I eat here about once a week, usually take out but when we have a chance we like to go in and enjoy a meal at the restaurant. Can't get enough of their pho! especially the Five spice chicken.
author: Christie S.

description: Worst Vietnamese of my life. No flavor, over cooked noodles, just a disaster. They were nice enough to comp our appetizer bc it was inedible, but the rest of the meal wasn't much better. Avoid at all costs
author: Matt A.

description: We ordered through eat24.  The food was top quality and fresh.  Delivery was prompt and corteous.  Their Imperial Rolls were not the best but good enough.  I will order from this place again.
author: Emilia G.

description: I cannot believe this family-owned restaurant has only 3.5 stars. I've been coming here for over two years and it is by far THE BEST pho in San Francisco. For a good time, order the RARE STEAK pho and a thai iced tea. The meat is so tender and juicy and broth is incredibly flavorful. So simple yet so, so delicious. Seriously, if I could give this place 10 stars, I would.
author: Allison D.

description:
I like Yummy Yummy, so the roommate and I decided to try Y&Y. Ordered delivery a few weeks ago through Eat24.

4. BBQ pork rolls ($6.95)
17. Raw beef salad with lemon juice, fish sauce, mint leaves, onion (no peanuts) $9.25
25. Combination beef noodle soup: with rare steak, well done flank, beef balls, tendon and tripe ($8.95)
36. Shrimp paste and tomato paste noodle soup, spicy ($8.50)
C. BBQ chicken sandwich ($4.95), add Pate (+$0.50)

I loved the raw beef salad. Great mix of flavors with the citrus, fish sauce and mint. My shrimp and tomato paste soup was also pretty good. I like my soup super spicy and fishy, so I could have used even more shrimp paste and spice. The pork rolls were good. Nice bbq flavor. The sandwich was kind of bland. Not much pickle flavor from the veggies, spice from jalapenos or freshness from cilantro. Plus, there just just the smallest swipe of pate. I expected a little more than that.

The huge disappointment of this entire meal was the pho. The roommate and I have had our fair share of mediocre bowls of noodle soup, but Y&Y's pho broth tasted like water. Granted, it was beef flavored water, but it was pretty bad. No amount of sriracha or hoisin sauce could save this soup. The roommate said this was the most unsatisfying bowl of pho he's ever had!

Ordering through eat24, we were charged a $3 delivery charge and a $7.04 service fee. This is the first time I've been subject to an 18% service fee. I've paid some small delivery fees before (anywhere between $1 and $3), but I've never had my order subject to a service charge that high. Not sure if eat24 or Y&Y is getting this charge, so I won't count it against them. But one thing to note is that it is more than Postmates, which has a 9% service fee.

I don't understand why people like Y&Y's pho. Maybe it was an off night, but I'll stick to Yummy Yummy instead.
author: Elena N.

description:
So I came to Y&Y a few weeks ago with some friends around dinner time on a random weekday, and the place wasn't that crowded and we got seated almost immediately (yay). I got the pork with vermicelli noodles and my other friends got the five-spice chicken with vermicelli noodles. The pork was flavorful and the noodles tasted pretty fresh, but when I tried my friends' chicken some parts were tough to chew... It could definitely have been more tender and flavorful.

Oh! One thing that I did like was their spring rolls!! They were crispy on the outside and chewy (in a good way haha) on the inside, and the texture was awesome and pretty unique compared to other spring rolls I've had. It wasn't crunchy and hard, but crispy and chewy. Mmm :)

Their service was great and they kept on refilling our waters, so that was a big plus! If I could I would give this place 3.5 stars, but since I can only pick between 3 or 4 I chose 3 because they were known for their Five-Spice Chicken with Vermicelli and it disappointed me and my friends; the dish wasn't as amazing as I had expected coming from previous customers. 

Overall this place is pretty solid, and on the cheaper side, so regardless of this review you should check it out if you're in the area!
author: Joy K.

description:
The best pho spots in San Francisco aren't Kevin Noodle House or PPQ, they're the tiny less known restaurants like Y&Y! 

I came right when they opened for dinner at 5:30pm on a Saturday and was seated right away. Customers started pouring in around 6. I was pleased to see that their menu included a lot of traditional Vietnamese dishes that most places in SF don't have like Bun Bo Hue and Banh Canh Cua. 
My party ordered the Carpaccio appetizer (raw beef), Pho Dat Biet, Beef rice plate, and Banh Canh Cua. The raw beef was perfectly thin. Some places have thicker cuts and its just kinda gross to have a mouthful of chewy raw meat. The Pho didn't stand out too much but it was still good. The Banh Cann Cua however, was the best I've had in SF! It's a seafood based thicker broth and it comes with two pieces of crab, pork, and pork blood. Yum. 

It surprises me that some reviews say that the service is bad. When I came I thought the waitress was great! She was so nice and made sure we were happy. I can't wait to try everything else on the menu!
author: Christine L.

description:
It has been awhile since I was last in the Outer Richmond District of the City. I have been on this Vietnamese food quest and today was just another place to add to my list. My lady picked this place from my bookmarked places on Yelp and we decided to try to this place. 

After finding a parking place I realized that I had been around this area before and had never seen this restaurant. There is a coffee shop across the street from Y & Y that I had been to before. Once I realized that I was familiar with the area I proceeded on towards Y & Y. First impressions, this place is small. Took a seat inside and was given a menu and began to review the menu items. I knew I wanted BEEF and that is exactly what I go. My lady got the SPRING ROLLS and some barbecue chicken with rice. 

I got the spicy beef soup and it was AMAZING. This was the first time that I could not finish my meal. I was even taken back that I left food in the bowl. They give you a big portion for the soup so you had better be HUNGRY and ready to CHOW DOWN. 

Good stuff here. Plus, they open early in the morning compared to some other places that do not open until noon time, that's always annoying. 

A nice place to come for lunch or brunch.
author: Robert F.

description:
The BBQ pork spring rolls are good, the banh xeo is crispy.  The curry chicken noodle soup is good, but not the best in the city.  Husband likes the 5 chicken noodle soup.
#glutenfree #dairyfree
author: Heather S.

description:
Y&Y was a mixed bag. I thought there were some good dishes and some that just didn't do it for me. The bun bo hue was alright. I thought some of the spices in the broth were too powerful to the point that I couldn't enjoy the flavor of the meat and the noodles too. It needed a bit more balance. The five spice chicken pho was alright. However, my boyfriend thought it was very good. He enjoyed the broth and the crispy skin of the chicken. Since the broth was clean and simple, it paired well with the fried chicken. Still, I wasn't completely sold and don't think I'd order it again. I thought the clear winner, though, was their imperial egg rolls. These were probably some of the better ones I've had in a long time. The wrapping was perfectly fried (nice and golden!) and the filling was delicious. I love that it came with a small garnish of greens and noodles too. 

The service was fine. The restaurant isn't very big, but it's orderly, efficient, and bright. It appears they have a solid clientele and a diverse one too -- younger, older, Asian, non-Asian, etc. Even at an off-hour (we went around 2 PM), it was relatively busy. Overall, Y&Y is alright but I'll need more convincing to go a second time.
author: James Z.

description:
Beef noodle soups are really good. 
the Fresh Pork rolls are also very yummy.
Never too long of a wait
author: Moto B.

description:
This is the sister store of Yummy Yummy on Irving. The food is above average. It is tastier than the vietnamese restaurants in Chinatown but can not compare with San Jose. 

On this day, I did not go with the individual dishes (i.e. pho / rice plate / etc.) Instead, I ordered family style entrees (shrimp papaya salad, grilled shrimp and grilled clams) to share. The grilled shrimp was good. The shrimp papaya salad was decent. The grilled clams was average. Overall, the objective of this meal was fulfilled - fill up my hungry stomach during lunch time.
author: Steven L.

description: We ordered the pho ga. The presentation was good but pretty much the whole thing was dark meat with a lot of fat hanging from it.
author: Damoon M.

description: Would eat here every week if I could. It's the sister restaurant to Yummy Yummy across the park.  My favorites are the curry chicken noodle soup, satay beef noodle soup, and the grilled meats you wrap yourself with lettuce, rice noodles and other veggies.
author: T T.

description: This is my favorite Vietnamese place in the city. They have the best five spice chicken I've had. It's seasoned perfectly, cooked perfectly and the skin is crispy. Their pho is also really good. The broth is flavorful, whether you get the beef broth or the chicken broth. Highly recommend this place.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I dont want no mediocre...I don't want no mediocre!!!

I think this place is mediocre, at best *sigh* -__-

OK, here's the thing. The location is prime and I think that's why they get so much business. There are just about a handful of Vietnamese restaurants in the area, but not so much a (pronounced fuh, not po or foe) Pho house. This place is kind of one of them.

$9.25 for one size bowl of pho, a bit on the pricey side.

The broth is visually oily..u can see little oil bubbles..and that's just how they make their pho and I don't like it.

The broth is not flavorful enough! It's not beefy, nor pork boney, or anise-y, and perhaps cardomom-ny enough! *Pho ingredients*

I've frequent this place from time to time and sadly, it's never hit the spot for me. I'm Vietnamese, so I've had my share of pho. Bottom line: service is friendly, and if your pho craving ensues, and you're in the area, then sure, go for it. But if u want better pho, hit the Sunset or the Tenderloin!
author: Victoria T.

description:
We ordered some food to go for lunch:

1. Grilled Pork Banh Mi - tasted fine
2. Fancy Pork w/ Pate Banh Mi - lacked in flavor. Fancy pork didn't seem fresh 
3. Grilled pork and fried spring rolls with vermicelli - pretty good. Spring rolls were nice and crisp
4. Pan seared Rice Cakes - pretty good
5. Rice with shredded pork - decent
6. Che Ba Mau (3 color bean dessert drink) - this was the worst CBM I've had. Ever. The coconut milk in the drink is meant to complement the sweet beans. Not Y&Y's version. Their's was 25% sweet beans and 75% coconut milk. So disappointed.

Overall, 2 1/2 stars
author: M T.

description: Did not like my beef stew with rice noodles. The meat didn't seem like it was cooked long enough and the soup tasted like tomato paste and water. I had to send it back. Going back to Kevin's Noodle House next time, they have the best beef stew and noodles. Everything else was just ok.
author: Bebe L.

description: The food is decent/good, but the service is lacking and bordering on rude. The head waitress is curt and it always seems like she's looking to somehow pick a fight with customers.
author: Rocky B.

description:
I went yesterday and I wasn't disappointed. Although the wait was long for our group of six, the waitress was super sweet and accommodating.

After getting seated, it took awhile to get their attention to take our orders. The waitress kept taking phone calls in the middle of taking our orders. 

I ordered the Combination Pho Beef Noodle Soup and thoroughly enjoyed it. Standard pho, but huge portions. If you're hungry and on a budget, check this place out.

The broth wasn't too salty. The noodles were cooked well (although they could have left boiled it 2-3 seconds longer). The meats were standard. I was hoping for more beef tendon though.

For $9.95, I left the restaurant feeling way over fed, but content at the same time. I was satisfied, but I'm damn sure I could have split that bowl with another person.

Overall, this is a decent pho restaurant that I wouldn't mind going back again.
author: Chinsin S.

description: My favorite Vietnamese spot in Richmond, same owners as yummy yummy on Irving. The restaurant is pretty small so it fills up quick during dinner time. The wait staff is very friendly and the food never disappoints. The raw beef salad appetizer is probably my favorite. I could eat the entire thing as my entree. Their vermicelli bowls and bun bo hue are also really good. Just don't wear a white shirt if you're planning on ordering the bun bo hue.
author: Linz C.

description:
Heard that this was the sister restaurant of Yummy Yummy on Irving. My boyfriend and I finally came around to trying out the place and ordered the same dishes we usually do at Yummy Yummy.

The verdict:

Bun Rieu - He and I prefer for the bun rieu at Yummy Yummy more. The broth here at this location was really lacking the tomato taste. 

Bun Bo Hue - Both of the bbh at both locations are quite similar. However, my bowl of bbh here did not have much noodles and meat compared to Yummy Yummy. My noodles were also either overcooked or just broken. 

Vietnamese grilled clams - He and I both agree that Y&Y's clams are well "washed". We didn't not taste the sand like we did at Yummy Yummy which we did not enjoy eating very much. The downside is that we weren't given as much clams for the price compared to Yummy Yummy.

I really enjoyed how Y&Y is much cleaner and newer compared to Yummy Yummy. Would we drive all the way to Y&Y or drive down the street to Yummy Yummy? We are still deciding ...
author: Kathleen U.

description:
This is definitely one of the best Vietnamese places I have ever been. It's definitely the best in the city. The staff is quick, friendly and efficient. The food is amazing! 

My boyfriend and I eat here at least once a week we love it so much! Some of our favorites are the Vietnamese pot stickers, chicken wings, house special grill, five spice chicken noodle soup and any of meat with vermicelli dishes. 

If you're in the city you have to try this place! The prices are great and the food is incredible.
author: Aria M.

description: I don't  know I might not come back I've been wanting to try this place for awhile and its always so busy so I though this place could be fine. What I order can go either way I got the chicken curry and it really was terrible . the chicken was broiled in some tasteless sauce and the curry was sour soup with bland chicken and over cooked. I ask for a roll to dip in to the sour soup curry mix that was the only way I could eat.
author: Seaera T.

description:
Whenever I go and eat Vietnamese food, I generally judge the place by a few things.  Their broth for the pho has to taste amazing on its own, before you add all the other stuff.  The rare beef has to be rare and very fresh, none of that floating bits of dried out already cooked flat beef.  Also, the imperial rolls have to be authentic.  What I love about Y&Y is that is has all of that.  Oh, and they also make great vietnamese sandwiches that are still under $5.  They use actual cilantro, not like that fake place down the street (Bahn Mi) that uses cabbage or cole slaw or something.
Its my go to place for pho, and for barbecue pork and imperial rolls over rice.
author: Onigiri A.

description:
I stumbled across this place as everything was shutting down early for New Years Eve. 
It's a little awkward waiting to be seated as it doesn't seem like any one person is in charge of it or that they have any kind of a system, so you awkwardly stand hovering over other diners in the doorway because the tables are so close to the door. 

Luckily we were seated in the back (I'm sure the seats in the front are cold from the door opening and closing so often). 

For an appetizer we ordered the spring rolls, they're okay but there's really not a lot that's in them and they're not rolled tight enough so everything falls apart after your first bite, but the presentation is nice. 

Otherwise we ordered two different bowls of pho. One with rare beef and beef balls, and another with rare beef, beef balls and tripe. We were actually surprised that the broth was really good! We didn't need to add a lot of sriracha or hoisin to either dish.
author: Mandi W.

description: Their banh mi is pretty good but not the best I've had. I wish they had jalapeño as a standard veggie. Also, they do sell out of their boba drinks midday.
author: michelle l.

description: Our go to Vietnamese spot on Clement. Tasty, reasonably priced, efficient service. It can get crowded if it is a cold night (which in the Richmond is often) and people are in the mood for soup, but we've never had to wait very long, if at all. Our usuals are combo beef pho, 5 spice chicken pho, and imperial or fresh spring rolls. Consistently good. Have also gotten bun and rice dishes, as well as the raw beef salad-nothing has ever been bad/disappointing.
author: Angela C.

description:
Reaching out, to bite a sando,
Electric banh mis everywheeeere.
See that fooood? It knows I'm biting.
It likes the waaaay I cheeeew!

If they say Y, & Y, tell 'em that it's hungry nature...
Y, & Y, does he order that way?

Dine-in-only items (like raw meats) can be available to-go.
Let them know you're going straight home right now to eat.
author: Dan B.

description: Kinda like a DIY spring roll Viet cuisine, they also serve pho but their spring rolls are to die for! Their Pork spring roll with bean sprouts, rice noodles, and lettuce is what I get every time!
author: Ken H.

description:
It rained hard today.  I was ready to have a good bowl of Udon crab soup with my 3 relatives.  Well, we went in, were sitting down when a waitress came over to reprimand us for dripping on the floor. There were no signs, no room nor a hanger for us to hang our jackets.  We had no choice but to hang our jackets on our chairs. 

She didn't stop.  It was how she said it that caused us to get up and leave.  We went to the Tasty Hotpot across the street on Clement between 9th and 10th.  That was a great decision.  The food at Tasty Hotpot excellent, and the service there was day and night comparing to Y & Y.
author: L T.

description:
I walked into this restaurant and I was immediately impressed by the modern decor and cleanliness of the place. Maybe I'm odd to note that. But oftentimes when I walk into Asian restaurants, I try not to think about my surroundings too much. lol. 

The menu has a wide variety of foods including banh mi (Vietnamese sandwiches), pho, bun (vermicelli), com dia (rice dishes), as well as smoothies and desserts. I ended up ordering the banh hoi (fine vermicelli) with thit nuong sa (lemongrass grilled pork). My cousin ordered the bun bo hue, which is a spicy beef noodle stew. 

I thought the dish I ordered was very delicious. It was a huge plate that included lettuce, mint, radish and carrots, cucumber, and bean sprouts on the side. The vermicelli was a little thicker than I'm used to but it was still good. The grilled pork was flavorful and topped with peanuts and onions. They provided spring roll wraps with a container of water so that you can put everything together yourself. It's definitely a hands on sort of meal. 

Service was good too. The server came by to check on us. She also informed us that it could take a little longer since I ordered the grilled pork. Overall, I enjoyed my experience at this restaurant and would definitely return.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Man, I was really craving Vietnamese food and Y & Y was a huge letdown. 

(-) their fish sauce tastes a bit off and isn't as flavorful as others that I've had 
(-) their imperial rolls lacked flavor
(-) pho broth was hot but lacked flavor too

All in all, everything was just meh and I wish I had gone down the street to the other numerous pho and noodle restaurants on Clement. The interior is clean and they had the Warriors game on, which I appreciated. I was a little confused because I ordered a lemon iced tea, and then asked if they could add boba in it after I saw it on the menu. The waitress told me that they don't have boba available, although it was on the menu. I decided to let it go because there was a language barrier and I didn't want to be a difficult customer- but then I saw them bring out a boba drink for the table next to me minutes later!!!! My friend and I were lost for words, maybe she didn't feel like helping me. 

Bummer. Won't be coming back.
author: Erica L.

description:
I absolutely love this place. I will never get sick of their pho. 

You can call me boring and bland, but I only eat pho or vermicelli at a Vietnamese restaurant (mostly pho, though). So unlike the other people who have gone here and ordered random stuff and have been disappointed, I'm always satisfied with my experience here haha. 

It's perfect for Sf's cold nights and the pho just hits the spot every time. It's reasonably priced and affordable. The people are very nice there as well and I've never had any trouble with their service. 

I don't have anything else to say- just to go try it out if are looking for a satisfying dinner and if it's your first time trying out pho, I highly recommend going here!
author: Momoe K.

description:
Sister restaurant to Yummy Yummy on Irving Street!  Food was tasty, service was quick, and prices are reasonable. 

Between the three of us, we ordered:

Red Bean Drink - Pretty good, but I wish there were more red bean in the drink.  Also, I wish the ice was shaved. 

Three Colored Drink - same comment as Red Bean Drink

BBQ Pork Rolls (6 pieces - $5.75) - I first had this roll when I visited Noodle Guy in So. Cal.  I was surprised to see that Y&Y offers this roll since I don't believe any other Vietnamese in the City sells this.  I'm guessing Vietnamese restaurants in the South Bay may carry this.  Anyway, the roll was delicious.  The BBQ pork was seasoned well and not dry.  Inside the roll is lettuce, BBQ pork, rice noodle, and mint.  The price is reasonable for the amount they give you.

Steamed Rice Cake with Shredded Pork & Fancy Pork (Banh Beo) ($7.75) - I first had this when I was in So. Cal as well.  I've searched high and low for this in the City, but didn't find a place that offered it until I came to Y&Y.  Although, I was disappointed as they make it completely different than Nem Nuong Ninh Hoa and Noodle Guy in So. Cal.  The Banh Beo at Y&Y is topped with yellow bean, shredded pork, and fancy pork.  The taste was okay.  I would pass on this.

Bun Rieu (7.95) - Perfect on a cold day!  It was delicious and extremely flavorful.   It's a tomato soup base with fried tofu, crab meat mixed with tofu, tomatoes, fancy pork, and topped off with green onions and fried shallots.  

I plan on coming back to try the Viet Grilled Clams and other items on their menu.
author: Candice H.

description: I came around 2pm and it was packed. I ordered #42 sate beef with rice noodles and the beef was extremely rare. I'm use to slightly pink meat because the soup would eventually cook it, but it took forever. Beef usually cook in one to two minutes. Overall, this order delicious
author: Vanessa Y.

description: Really disappointed this time. Rude waitress didn't explain the menu well. Not sure I will visit again.  Also one thinly cut pork chop with 2 small shrimp an egg roll with rice and an egg for$12?  Most places would give you 2 thin cut pork chops.  Maybe they don't value customers as much as they use to.   Disappointed.  Really disappointed
author: Doug W.

description:
Great clean restaurant serving good pho. I had the 5 spice chicken pho and it was pretty dynamite. Probably not as authentic as some in the tenderloin...but still solid.
One of my dinning partners had the spicy curry chicken pho....it was spicy....but we like it like that ....oh yeah.

Service is very friendly, fast and efficient. 

Good selection of appetizers and other things. So three big steaming bowls of Pho were 25 bucks....not bad.

Check it out!
author: David G.

description:
It's Yummy Yummy's sister restaurant! (The one on Irving next to San Tung)
The menu is roughly similar, but the food is FAR from delicious, and portions on appetizers are a joke. Felt so ripped off. 

Deep Fried Chicken wings - Bleh. Can't compare to the one at Yummy Yummy. It's supposed to be the same recipe, and the sauce is similar, but it's far from being the same. Can skip this.

Raw beef salad - Portion is tiny, very flavorless and not worth your time. 

Imperial Rolls - It tasted alright, but it only comes with 5 MEASLY little pieces. Who are you trying to feed? a baby? It wasn't even enough to feed our party of 6 so one of us had to skip.  As reference, its smaller than the size of my thumb length wise. 

I didn't get the "specialty" phos, but my friends did and they were pretty damn disappointed with that as well."Bland crap noodle" as they called it. One of them had a crab pho(?) and it was goopy. Yes, GOOPY. It looked like food fit for an extraterrestrial being. 

Only redeeming dish that the other 3 of us got, the number 59 rice plate with a bit of everything. Very flavorful. Beef was good, comes with an imperial roll that was way bigger than what was served to us in the appetizer plate. 

I wouldn't come back here. We only came here because the original restaurant was closed and we needed to eat at a place that didn't have a long line.
Overall, save yourself the trouble and don't come here unless most of everything else is closed in the area.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Y & Y is definitely one of my favorite pho restaurants in SF. Its sister restaurant is Yummy Yummy in Inner Sunset, which I also really like!

I almost always order Pho Tai at any pho place I visit, and this is hands down the best I've eaten. It comes with so much meat and unlike other Pho Tai I've had, Y & Y's steak is actually served rare and cooks in the delicious broth. The meat is really tender and the texture of the noodles are perfect. Definitely hits the spot. I've also ordered their BBQ beef spring rolls both times I've been here because they're so good. I love living so close to amazing Asian food.

Tip: they're closed on Tuesdays.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
This place is pretty small and clean comparing it to most Vietnamese pho places.

Came here after an event with a bunch of friends. They took our order fairly quickly.

I ordered the 5 spice chicken noodle dish. It was not bad considering the chicken was not dry but perfectly cooked. I had better at Ben Tre for 5 spice chicken dishes compare to here.

But overall not bad food or experience here, just okay. 4 star is for the perfectly cook chicken!
author: Steven C.
Em T.

description:
Kind of a small/medium sized restaurant. Went on a Monday around lunch time and it was packed. 

Ordered #21, #39 and Bun Bo Hue. The Bun Bo Hue was good! They had the thin noodles instead of the fat noodles and they didn't have the typical vegetables that come with Bun Bo Hue. They did have bean sprouts though. 

#39 is good if you like thick crab soup! And pig blood. #21 was a nice appetizer. I would recommend it for someone who wants to try a new Vietnamese dish. 

Great customer service- help response was quick and they were kind.
author: Anna H.

description:
my go-to spot for bun bo hue when in inner richmond! really hits the spot on cold days (and let's be honest, there's more than just a handful of those in sf) or after a good workout when i want to gain back all the calories i just worked off!

the bun bo hue broth has great depth and flavor. the bowl comes packed with noodles and all the different meats you expect to see in bun bo hue, but isn't overwhelmed by onions and cilantro. just the way i like it! the "regular" is probably a "large" anywhere else, so it's great value for your money. 

there hasn't been too long of a wait here during weekend lunches when i've dined between the peak hours of 11am-2pm over the past couple of months. i'm hoping that doesn't change now that WINTER IS COMING and i'm expecting more rainy days (more like praying for snow) in the near future.
author: Yiwen S.

description:
I'm very perplexed about this restaurant. 

We order:
Banh beo,
Clams.
Bun Bo Hue
Banh canh cua.

I will pick my bone with the bun bo hue. It has all the right ingredients of a bun bo hue. Broth was good, flavor was ok. But it was NOT bun bo hue. If it was called pork soup or by any other name, it would be a decent bowl of soup. But it didn't taste like bun bo hue. If you are looking for an authentic bowl of bun bo hue, this is not the place for you. I was in the SF area and had a crazy craving for bun bo hue. I ate the entire bowl, it was a decent bowl of soup but I could not come to the conclusion if it was bun bo hue.

I think the same can be said of the other items we ordered. The foods were not bad, it was just not what it should be. To simply put, it's "Vietnamese" foods made for non-Vietnamese. 

What is most perplexing is the entire menu is Vietnamese. At first glance it was an impressive variety. Some of dishes you don't see even in most Authentic Vietnamese restaurants. But after 4 orders, it was clear this restaurant is not meant for those who know Viet foods.

I would give this restaurant 3 stars on taste alone, but only 2 stars because of inauthenticity. You can call your dish anything you want, but if you call it pho, it must taste like pho. And if you call it bun bo hue (my speciality ;)), then darn it, it must taste like bun bo hue!
author: Quinn V.

description: Lackluster for me. I also prefer banh mi elsewhere, the ones here are made somewhat crudely. Would probably only re-order if in a pinch.
author: R.E. B.

description:
The banh can cua was soso. I think my canh is better and this other place in Milpitas called Truong Thanh.

The consistency was watery and the noodles were very soft.  They break apart when you touch them with your chopsticks.
Also it only comes with two TINY claws for crab meat. 
It was lacking flavor as well.
I did enjoy the grilled clams but there were only 12 clams in this dish which came out to a dollar a clam. The portion was too tiny, I could've probably had three more plates.
author: Heejin L.

description: I have eaten here a couple of times and two of the three times were in-house with one takeout.   Each time I ate in the food was delicious.  The five spice chicken was delicious.  The one time I ordered takeout the chicken was definitely from the day before as it was dry and tough.  Huge disappointment.  I would've brought it back but didn't want to lose my parking space in the neighborhood where I live.  I guess I won't order takeout anymore.
author: Susan L.

description:
Clean, flavorful, attentive, and they don't give you crap for splitting the check with 5 credit cards.

I have a bi-monthly pho club, and we've tried other places, but this place just always works out. We always get a table, the broth is flavorful, they have good drinks, and the service is good!
author: Genevieve L.

description: Been here a couple of times and loved the beef pho. The broth is so favorable and the beef was tender and chewy. Clean place and you can see how they prepare the food in the kitchen. It is always good to know how your food is being cooked.  The servers are friendly and the bathroom is very clean.
author: William J.

description: I loved the vegetarian pho, but the vegetarian spring rolls were extremely "meh." The tofu felt dry and thin. I'll come back for the pho, but will skip the rolls next time. Another plus: the kitchen appeared to be clean, the service was friendly, and the dining area appeared to be comfortable (although I ordered take-out).
author: Elizabeth C.

description: I ordered my favorite "Tomato crab noodle soup" (good as always) and their price went up a little! Friendly servers ^^
author: Wendy L.

description:
Had their:

Shrimp papaya salad (hefty serving and their fish sauce isn't very salty, but missing peanuts)

Pork skin fresh rolls (delicious, not too fatty and meat to vegetables ratio is perfect)

Vietnamese coffee (asked for less condensed milk and it was just how I like it, slightly sweet and bitter)

Their service was nice and attentive.
author: Jannies L.

description:
I was attracted to the fact that they are a sister company of  Yummy Yummy on Irving Street.

Based on the five spice chicken with vermicelli & Imperial rolls... I have to say my experience is that the Irving St location is the better sibling.
author: Dijana S.

description:
Far from pho-nominal.

Came with a friend to try the eats today. She had the charbroiled pork vermicelli bowl and I had a rare steak and flank pho. Both bowls were topped to the brim with food - awesome.

Despite having a very good ratio of meat to noodles in my pho, the whole experience was dampened by the fact that the broth just didn't have enough flavor. The noodles were also a little underdone for my liking. My friend fully vouches for her vermicelli bowl though - flavors were on point and the charbroiled pork was done nicely. 

In terms of the restaurant itself, it's very small...and pretty easy to miss. I also don't really care for any restaurant that ops to use disposable utensils versus real ones. But the real "miss" for me was the service. It took a good 10 minutes for us to get a waiter to take our order and another 15 minutes for our food to come out - that's pretty darn slow for a pho place.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Small and Nice place to dine. Suitable for lunch and dinner here. Casual and nothing fancy or complicated. Authentic Vietnamese Cooking and I love their Pho. Definitely a place that I will visit frequent ^^
author: Unyo N.

description:
Definitely he best Banh Xeo I've had outside my gramma's kitchen. Been searching for years for such a place and thought that none existed. So crispy on the outside while keeping moist within!

Banh Mi sando was good too. Bread is tasty and toasted. I had the nem nuong (fried meatball) and it was quite delish. A bit pricey for Banh Mi, but good.
author: Norman Q.

description:
Went here for a quick lunch with my mom.

I ordered a tomato and shrimp paste pho while she ordered a beef pho.

This place is pretty average. Nothing too special or amazing going on.  Something that was nice was that you have the option for raw or steamed sprouts. That was interesting.

The food is decently surprised. The pho only comes in one size and I'd saw it's about a medium at any other Vietnamese restaurant. This place is a bit pricier than other Vietnamese restaurants. Many of the non noodle soup based dishes range up to $20.

My pho was not hot enough. The flavor was lacking and there were only three pieces of shrimp paste. Our food had definitely been sitting at the counter for a while. The beef pho was much hotter and flavorful. Out of our two dishes hers was much better.
author: Julia Q.

description:
This place is the bomb. I know there are quite a few incredible Vietnamese restaurants in the city but this one is really addictive. There are so many things I want to try on their menu, like their BBQ pork rice plates, vermicelli bowls, and spicy pho. Prices are great and interior is very clean. Service is wonderful.  Wish they had longer hours though, I'm sure many would appreciate take out on those late summer nights. 

They have tons of Vietnamese style iced drinks as well. I feel like I'm gonna come here on a weekly basis now that I'm getting a little tired of King of Thai noodles just a few blocks down (different things, I know, but still). So good I keep craving it.
author: Jackie C.

description:
Like eating at Yummy Yummy but sans the wait and higher price tag! HAH!

Key things to order: bo tai chanh / raw beef salad. Exactly the same great taste but a couple bucks less than getting it at Yummy Yummy. They charge somewhere close to $14 whereas at Y&Y it's about $8. I know, pretty big price difference right? So not worth waiting around at Yummy Yummy now that I know I can just head to Y &  Y. 

Ngheu xao la que / viet grilled clams. I LOVE THIS STUFF. They're steamed and grilled with peants garlic fish sauce green onions. It's about $10 at Yummy Yummy. I don't remember the price tag at Y & Y because they only had enough clams to make me half an order :[ so they had to charge me less. 

Ordered the fish sauce lemongrass fried chicken. These are tiny little drumlettes deep fried and smothered in sauteed onions and lemongrass dripping with fish sauce. So tasty! 

Pho is standard. Broth is a bit better than at Yummy Yummy that is for sure. I normally don't order regular pho, I always have bun bo hue or bun rieu but I found myself liking Y & Y's. 

Funny how it's nearly the same restaurant but I can't really stand Yummy Yummy. Definitely a fan of Y & Y though.
author: Susy C.

description:
Standard pho place. Can't say it's any better or worse than any other pho place I've been. Prices are more than reasonable and you can get bahn mi's as well along with other Chinese like dishes.

Parking on Clement is always bad. I don't remember if they have the stereotypical aquarium with a turtle and one fish in it - it's better they don't because those tanks are so gross.
author: Julia P.

description: Not coming back again. I won't say it's an authentic Vietnamese restaurant, plus the beef doesn't taste fresh, shrimp rolls (appetizer) is the worst.
author: Tina C.

description:
OMG! We freakin love this place, we go here so often for lunch or dinner that the waitresses know us already. 

All their food is super yummy, it's our go to comfort food when we are at work, because it is only a few minutes away.

Y&Y is cute and intimate and if you come during the lunch/dinner rush, you may have to wait a bit for a seat, but believe me the food is worth it! 

Some of our favorites:

The eggrolls which are filled with shrimp, veggies, and noodles.....ahhhhh so good!
Any of the meats charbroiled, so delicious I could eat it everyday!!!!!
author: Alejandra I.

description:
Solid Vietnamese place.  

The fresh veggie spring rolls and the bbq pork rolls were really good.  The BBQ pork was perfectly seasoned and perfectly cooked.

Most of us got the pho, as we were having a craving.  An average bowl is about 8 dollars, which may be on the more expensive side when it comes to pho on clement street, but the quality was good.  The rare beef slices (pho tai) were pretty tender. 

One star comes off for service.  They only had two people working the front, and so we had to wave them down to take our order and for the check at the end.  They could have turned over a lot more tables had they had more people helping out (as there was a steady line of people out the door on a Sunday afternoon).
author: Alison L.

description:
We ate here on a Thursday night, 715pm. I ordered the 5 spice soup with a vietnamese coffee. We had two small children with us and the staff was considerate enough to offer us high chairs. 

The service was great. No wait time at arrival. And they served us very promptly. No one table had too much time with the server. 

The 5 spice soup comes in with fried chicken on the side and a bowl of noodles with soup. And the vietnamese coffee comes with a process, that nobody explained to me. I was able to figure it out, but I would assume less adventurous people would get lost. 

The soup was good, but I was exhausted. I really didn't wanna have to disassemble a chicken and toss it in my soup. Because of this, I enjoyed the company of my friends more than I did the soup. 

The bathroom is alot like how most asian places in this area. 

Paying was a breeze. We didn't have to get up.
author: John C.

description: The food is pretty okay but the server is not nice. We sit there for like 15 mins when there is no other customers in the restaurant, and there are like 3 servers standing there. Only one can speak English properly so I have to wait for her to take orders. She is grumpy for both times we came there. I have been to many Viet places in SF and haven't seen someone that unhappy when taking customer orders. There are better places in the area with better service. If you just care about your food, go for it. Mien ga, grilled pork, vermicelli bowl are good here.
author: Tran N.

description:
Been to Yummy Yummy multiple times food and service has always been great there. Was on Clement, so decided to come here since it's their sister restaurant. Food was good but service here sucks! Don't know if it's because there's no one here that manages them but I'm never going to come back here again. 

Also, their foods a bit pricey! 4 pieces of imperial roll will cost you $8!
author: michele h.

description:
Sister restaurant of Yummy Yummy on Irving. This location has a similar (but smaller?) menu and is also smaller in size. However the food is equally *yummy* and is a good option if you don't want to trek down to the Sunset location. Pho with rare steak had great broth (albeit a little salty) and tender meat. The five spice chicken plate is good as well. Fried spring rolls are tasty but they only come with 4 pieces :(

This place closes sort of early so try to get there before 830 on week nights!
author: J L.

description:
Really enjoyed my meal here. Ate the BBQ Pork fresh roll to start and the beef combi pho for main. The rolls were delicious and fresh. The pork was nice and crispy without being greasy. 

The pho was equally nice and was a very generous portion. 

The restaurant service was great too. I will make this a regular stop.
author: Michael O.

description: Worst Vietnamese restaurant I ever visit.Starting with staff:the lady who served us was very unpleasant and didn't want to normally response on the question.The prawns with lemongrass it's not prawns- regular 4 shrimp served on top of iceberg lettuce(it's lemon grass!!) 15$.Apparently 1shrimp is 4$!!! Seasonal soup with meat and crab is horrible- my stomach hurt me whole day.Please be careful where you go and order.
author: Olga G.

description:
This place gets a star just for reasonable dinner prices for SF.  My five spice chicken pho was good and filling.  My boyfriend was happy with his veggie, pho but definitely not blown away.  That said it was veggie pho, so that is inevitable.   

I was happy and would go back.
author: Courtney C.

description:
egg rolls fried were very good.

pho tai broth was weak.  flavorless.

a bit disappointed since Irving street yummy yummy is hella awesome.
author: Kevin L.

description:
15.08.24.    1st

Food              3 1/2 -  3 3/4
Service.         4 -  4 1/2

Service
  3 person on my visit
  Narrow  layout allows easy peripheral view
  Attentive
  Newly arrived customer asked for water
     The other staff brought it to the table under 4 sec

Five spice chicken & imperial roll in cold noodles
  Slivers of basil made it taste Better
author: S.K. Y.

description: Four stars for their chicken pho. Their beef pho was a little underwhelming so if you're coming here, get the chicken pho. Other than that, a pretty standard vietnamese restaurant with nothing that will blow your mind.
author: Derrick W.

description: I always order the 5 spice chicken vermicelli for delivery and it's always so good! The chicken is perfectly crispy and delicious. The imperial rolls that come with it are also delicious. Definitely the best vermicelli I've had delivery or not!
author: Irina M.

description:
My moms favorite spot.

Soups are off the hook.
Big and flavorful. Lots of stuff and chunky meat!!

You can't be an imperial roll without meat. So not a fan.

Can't serve Com dam without traditional egg loaf aka ja.
But their fried egg is uniquely creamy good try.

Appitize of raw meat looks like layers of meat.
But was actually just one thin layer.

My family ordered the Soups and rice plates. Those were epic!!

Jackfruit smooth was cool.

Didn't get to try their Ban Mei aka Vietnamese sandwhich.

Looking forward to round2.
author: Hung L.

description:
IMO this is one of the best pho joints in the city. It's not particularly cheap nor particularly expensive but I always leave this place feeling satisfied. My favorite is the five spice chicken w/ imperial rolls over the dry vermicelli. The chicken is moist, has great flavor. There's a good portion of fresh veggies that come with your noodles + just the right amount of dipping sauce. It's great if you don't want to eat anything particularly heavy or filling.

The beef pho is flavorful hits the spot during cold days but they skimp on the noodles. I've seen many other places in the city give larger portions than this place for a similar price & quality.

Service is quick and attentive. Parking sucks around here though so be prepared to walk (off your calories gained).
author: Shirley N.

description:
Went over the weekend. Daughter was sleeping in the stroller so I waited before entering. The worker said to follow him so we did. The other worker, some angry looking lady, said "STOP! Wait NO room!"  Man, I swore her toes curled up and her fangs came out. Anyway, I waited alright, at another restaurant!

I'm sure the food's good, but regardless, I'm never setting foot in there again.
author: diewney n.

description:
What I have seen in the restaurant: I seen a worker in the back behind the counter drop food on the table and returns it back on the plate, umm ok... I also seen a cook or dish washer drop a plate on the ground and it shattered into small pieces. I also see the waiters aren't that mean, okay altitude and service. 
Besides that, I think the food does taste pretty good though. I like the chicken rice dish and pork rice dish.
Overall, I think the food is pretty good, and fairly clean I guess, but the price isn't very cheap. They should maybe lower the price by $.50 so get a Five Star atleast.
author: Kevin Z.

description:
Read someone's review about how being Non Asian resulted in less than stellar service....came today for lunch with the folks and all I could notice was how "typical rude Asian service" we got from the lady and how the white guy at the table next to me was being treated so courteously and kindly....wtf.....another "typical" Asian trait that I have long forgotten about. 

Food took a ridiculous amount of time to come, but when it did, it smelled so great and fragrant. 

Flavor wise, it was pretty good. Don't know if I'd make a special trip out here good. Service was slow, extremely slow, and inconsistent, hence 3 stars
author: Thuy M.

description: Been here a couple of times and I'm very happy with their services and the food is consistently good. It's hard to find authentic Vietnamese food and some of their dishes are pretty darn good.
author: Blanca W.

description: We had the BBQ pork sandwich, and it was deliciousness! The flavors exploded in your mouth, cucumbers and fixings on the sandwich were fresh and the bread was perfect; crusty and soft inside! We are coming back when we are in Richmond!
author: Karen S.

description:
Sister restaurant of Yummy Yummy in the Sunset district, serving a smaller but hearty menu of mostly Noodle Soups, Rice Plates and Vermicelli. 

Everything is really flavorful and very tasty. The soup/broth is never bland. Excellent Imperial Rolls. One of our favorites for casual Vietnamese fare.
author: Jing D.

description:
#42, sate beef noodle soup, is incredible. Spicy, peanut-y broth with rice or egg noodles and rare beef. Super tasty, kind of reminds me of a mix between pho and ramen. 

The vermicelli noodle bowls and imperial rolls were solid too. Great option for an inexpensive meal. Highly recommend this place!
author: Brett K.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here to eat to get a late lunch. We had been lazy all morning and he was in a craving for Vietnamese food. The only other Vietnamese restaurant we've been to in SF is Yummy Yummy, which is the sister restaurant to Y&Y. We liked Yummy Yummy so there was no doubt that we wouldn't like this restaurant also. 

Because it was the late afternoon, there restaurant wasn't too full and we were able to be get seated right away. For an appetizer, we ordered spring rolls. I had Bun Bo Hue and my boyfriend had Imperial Rolls with Five Spice Chicken. The spring rolls were huge! Too many noodles in my opinion, which meant that as soon as I took a bite, the roll kind of broke apart or things started to fall out. There was also a chili pepper picture next to the Bun Bo Hue, so I knew it would be spicy but I wasn't expecting for it to be THAT spicy. If you like that burning feeling on your lips, then this will definitely do that for you. The Imperial Rolls and the Five Spice Chicken was something new to me. I personally did not enjoy them as much as my boyfriend. Maybe I don't like the change from ordinary egg rolls to Imperial rolls. It seemed like it was made with a different paper because they came out fried differently. 

Overall, this place was pretty good. We were immediately given a pot of hot tea as we got seated. If you listen closely, you can hear the faint Vietnamese music in the background of the restaurant. Only pet peeve: I ordered in Vietnamese and I don't think our waiter was Vietnamese. I felt dumb. Hahaha
author: Cathie N.

description:
We LURVE this little Vietnamese spot.  They used to be inside an Asian grocery store on Clement St. by 8th and we used to go there almost every other Sunday to share one of their awesome and bargain bahn mi's and chicken noodle soup (with the vermicelli noodle option)  for brunch between ourselves.  

As many bahn mi aficionados know, the perfectly baked and toasted bread that completes this stye of sandwich can make or break it.  Bahn mi's must be a careful combo of the baked, then toasted French roll and the contents inside, including the pickled veges, jalapenos, which give it the slight heat, crisp and tangy offset to the array of pate and BBQ meats.  

We love our bahn mi's,  we love it here best, and we are so stoked Y&Y re-opened in a new space on 914 Clement St (by 10th Ave) after almost a year they moved out of their other location.  

What makes their chicken noodle soup stand out is their fresh made daily home made chicken broth and the optional vermicelli noodles (no longer an option on their new menu, you'll have to ask the server), not the standard "pho ga" type noodles most of us are familiar with.  The lady who worked there before, who we recognized when we went in on Friday 29JUN12 (a day after their grand opening in their new spot), must be one of the owners, and we were glad to see her still there, smiling and proud of her new set up.

Their new location takes over the recently retired brothers who owned the Japanese restaurant Miyoshi's that used to be in this spot.  It's great to have actual tables to sit down at now, spread out, a larger menu selection, and they also now have BEER.  

We also tried their deep fried chicken wings for the first time on Friday and those were pretty darn tasty too.  They even prepare them with the little "French style handles" for easier grasping and eating.  

We look forward to trying new and different things on their expanded menu, but we know that we can always count on their bahn mi's and their chicken noodle soup.  We hope they can keep up the quality and taste standards they had when they were just the little hole in the wall deli.  From what we could tell when we tried them the other night, we were not disappointed.  Our every other Sunday brunch ritual at this little affordable, tasty Vietnamese gem is back on our lifestyle schedule for SF living.

Y&Y is one of those small businesses that makes SF such a great city for food (affordable eats too) and the Inner Richmond neighborhood a destination street for us.  Burma Star, Green Apple Books, Genki Crepes, Thai Time, Kamei, May Wah Market, Y&Y are some of the best things about cruising around on this street on weekends.

BTW, Y&Y = Yummy and Yummy.
author: Patrick M.

description:
I love their beef soups, Perfect.

Suggestion to Y & Y : beef broth : if you could use real beef broth that would be fantastic.Most of the time, the restaurant is busy with to go order.
author: Ryan S.

description: Great barbecue pork roll, awesome imperial rolls and the bun bo hue was nicely spiced and meaty! On top of that the customer service excellent.
author: Liz D.

description: Everything was just OK for take-out.  I enjoyed the raw beef salad.  Shrimp spring rolls were a bit gummy and the chicken wings were tasty but not very presentable with the side of onion sauce.  I may try their cold noodles with vermicelli again, if in the 'hood.
author: Rick W.

description:
So excited that my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in SF has finally decided to open an offshoot at my neck of the woods.  Once the owner at Yummy Yummy in the Inner Sunset let me know Y & Y was opened, I had to give it a try.  

The selection is scaled down to the variety at Yummy Yummy an the restaurant is about half the size.  However, they still have the staples like noodle soups and spring rolls. 

They also serve banh mi sandwiches for which I highly recommend.  The bread is perfectly toasted and the fillings are generous.  It is a steal for about $4.  It has been pretty busy already mirroring the success they have had at their Inner Sunset location.
author: Danny P.

description:
Excellent Pho! Try the 5-Spice Chicken Pho Ga, it's amazing! The chicken comes on a side plate if you'd prefer to eat it separately, or cut it up and add it in the Pho.

The staff was attentive, but could have checked on our table a bit more. 

Give this place a shot if you're in the area and looking for good Pho in San Francisco.
author: Bryan B.

description:
I am glad finally there is another authentic Vietnamese restaurant on Clement street. I think they just opened recently and place was packed during lunch time, the dinning area is not that big seats maybe 30ppl max. They have varieties of Vietnamese dishes from the sandwich to pho to rice dishes. They also have a pretty good drink menu. 

Since we were starving we ordered the following:
1) Shrimp spring rolls, taste just like the ones out there nothing special, the dipping sauce was a bit sweet.

2) Lemon beef, raw beef with peanut and lemon sauce, one of the best! if you like beef carpaccio this is the Vietnamese version of it

3) Pho, of course you have to order the pho to see whether this restaurant is authentic or not and I have to say theri PHO is one of the best I ever tasted

4) Five Spice chicken with rice, also one of the best I ever tasted, but I have to say the other Vietnamese restaurant down the street is a bit better but YY's its not bad at all.

For drinks we ordered the Viet ice coffee and grass jelly both were great! The other plus is for the wait staff, they were actually very friendly and helpful, smiles a lot and willing to help you. It might the reason that they just opened for business but I think they were great! I will be back to try more of their food. Great experience! try it!
author: William C.

description:
Their first restaurant Yummy Yummy is one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the city. We found out they expanded their location on clement street and decided to have lunch there. Husband order the Satay beef noodle and I had Bun Bo Hue. 
Satay beef noodle: its good but need more Satay flavor, but the quality of beef is fresh and tender. 
Bun Bo Hue: tasty broth with tender beef shank meat.  The portion was just right. Its not the best I ever had but decent around the area. 

The place is kinda small, they can accommodate probably about 35-40 people at a time. Please keep up the good work.
author: Jade P.

description:
When you go to write a review & choose which stars you want to give - 2 stars says, "Meh. I've experienced better." 

As for Y&Y, I've definitely experienced better.
